text: So... Kim wanted to partly denuclearize, for a partly lift of the sanctions. Trump wanted the full denuclearization so Kim wanted the full lift of sanctions. Sounds fair so far. So what was the Problem? By keeping the sanctions up, people are at the risk of starving over there. The nuclear program is the only card NKorea can play and a card they have worked on for a decade. The deal - as they wanted it - was the only option (partly/partly | fully/fully). Why didn't they just make it? I get why they didn't lift the sanctions fully yet, but then you just can't demand the full denuclearization as well... That's just the obvious. So as it stands, this wasn't more than a step back and a waste of money and time. Nontheless I'm happy they are talking at all. And I have the highest hopes for another meeting. its a compromise on both sides. trump understands this like most common sense ppl do. 
no nation wants to give up its self defense. rightly so. however they can have self defense in areas that do not place their neighbors in an immediate threat. 
nukes can deter attacks without placing their neighbors in that immediate threat. no one wants a nuclear weapon to be detonated near any population or to see nuclear weapons be launched in retaliation even if they can be taken out. 
we have a certain time limit to take missiles already in the air out. this is why certain areas need to be denuclearized that pose a threat that are within striking range underneath that time limit.
it is top secret but we have certain weapons that can take any missile out of the air that is not travelling a certain speed that nothing that contains mass can reach (yet). our systems just need a certain amount of time to lock on and project the missiles speed and flight path.
just research laser weaponry. our laser weapon speeds are not restricted by mass during the travel time they are restricted by the time it takes to plot path and speed of projectile they will be shooting down.
this is why we are looking for specific areas to be denuclearized rather than the entire nation.Ôªø

text:
@Don Farmer , man, that's dumb.  There really isn't any more testing NK could have done without recourse by a foreign power and their testing netted them the best results a nation their size could have ever hoped for: militaristic recognition by a superpower and a personal meeting with their leader.  NK knows that if they actually fired a live warhead targeting a foreign asset, it would be game over for the whole country.  Not to mention, the only time NK has ever openly threatened the US with a potential nuclear strike has been under Trump's administration in 2017, despite Trump's claims that we were closer to war under Obama.

On Trump's "deal-closing:" it's obvious he owes most of what he has to his father, from inheriting his already successful real estate business, to numerous gifts and loans totaling many millions.  He would have been an absolute failure if he wasn't able to maintain profits with a system already staffed and networked to do so and deep-pocketbooks to buffer it when it teeters.  All of his other failed enterprises, defaulted loans, and bankruptcies speak against his personal ability as a salesman/businessman in general, but he does have some skill in building and selling his "brand" (mostly through dishonestly inflating successes and values).  This compares more with commercialized athletes and modern day social media "influencers" than it does with high-rise businessmen, though, and he still pales in comparison to many who are less than a third his age.Ôªø

text:
‚Äã@Don Farmer , "in construction," hahaha.  Fred Trump was a real estate developer and his real estate company, E. Trump & Son, was renamed The Trump Organization.  Real good job with that one.  I also love how the go-to is always "most successful people have failures and bankruptcies."  Sure, some do, but successful people rarely default on so many high-value loans that they become blacklisted by all major US banks - you have to both fail enormously at your business ventures and have a serious record of not paying what's owed for that.  If Trump wasn't bailed out by the banks in the 90's (to protect their own interests) his business would have completely tanked.

Between loans (mostly un-repaid), gifts, and inheritance, Fred Trump gave Donald over $400M.  This is now public knowledge.
Again, Trump rebounded from the 90's and 2000's by selling his brand, not by being an expert real estate developer.  He put a lot of effort into convincing everyone, including those he was in business with, that he was worth more than he was - that the "Trump" brand represented elite, high-class value - and he found buyers because people still believed him.
It doesn't matter if you want to disregard this public information as "hateful Trump news," because the majority of it is derived from court records, Trump family tax returns, and bank receipts.Ôªø
